sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: YOU'RE WATCHING EURONEWS TONIGHT. I'M RAYNA ZAYDI. THESE ARE THE HEADLINES THIS HOUR.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: THE EU'S TOP DIPLOMAT JOSEPH BORRES CALLS RUSSIA'S BLOCKADE OF UKRAINIAN GRAIN EXPORTS A REAL WAR CRIME AS FOREIGN MINISTERS MEET IN LUXEMBURG.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: PREPARING FOR THE WORST-CASE SCENARIO, GERMANY ANNOUNCES PLANS TO BOOST ITS GAS STORAGE FOR WINTER, BUT ALSO TURNS BACK TOWARDS COAL TO MEET ITS ENERGY NEEDS. Germany announces plans to boost its gas storage for winter, but also turns back towards coal to meet its energy needs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: After failing to secure an outright majority in parliamentary elections, the scramble is on to win over new allies of France's President Macron and keep his plans for reform on track.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And as the world marks World Refugee Day, we'll take a look at the unprecedented number of people displaced by the unprecedented number of crises this year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Good evening. The EU's foreign affairs chief, Joseph Borre, says Russia is committing a war crime by blocking food exports from Ukraine's Black Sea ports. With the bloc's foreign affairs ministers gathering in Luxembourg, Borre appealed to Moscow to

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: lift the blockade or risk exasperating the global food crisis. Borre said there's a risk of famine in the world, especially in Africa, as the consequence of an increase in food prices coupled with an ongoing energy supply shortfall. He also defended EU sanctions against Russia saying they were not to blame for the food emergency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well let's cross over to Brussels and speak to Meg McMahon who's been following the story. Meg, good to see you there. So this morning Borre called the Russian blockade of Ukrainian exports a war crime. What more have foreign ministers had to say?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Mariam. Well, Joseph Borreia, the EU's foreign affairs chief, not mincing his words there, calling a spade a spade, saying that the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, was accountable for what he called this war crime, for blocking 20 million tons of grain and not giving access to people who are waiting for that food, who are reliant on that food coming from Ukraine across the globe. He said that Vladimir Putin was ultimately responsible and very much accountable, that he couldn't use the hunger of people as a weapon. But what he also used his press conference to do was to make sure that the message wasn't out there, that the and the european sanctions were to blame for this global food crisis and insecurity because of course we heard from african leaders that he's been conversing with that it is in fact those european sanctions that are to blame but he today said that was not the case he'd be sending quote comfort lectures to african nations and to economic leaders in order to make sure it was crystal clear that it wasn't these sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: You can see Joseph Borre between a rock and a hard place really because on the one hand he has ministers as well inside that room in Luxembourg today, especially the Polish minister calling on the EU to go a step further, in fact to go on for its seventh package of sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But on the other hand he's being blamed for the global food insecurity and also the cost of living crisis. If you look at here in Belgium today, thousands of people taking to the streets, blaming those sanctions and blaming inflation for the fact that they just can't afford to go shopping even anymore, and they've no money left in their pockets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And Maeve, it's also an important week for Ukraine and their European ambitions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Are there any signs in Luxembourg that Ukraine is ebbing closer to securing this EU candidate status at this week's EU summit?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, that was a huge topic of conversation today in Luxembourg, because, of course, EU heads of state and government will be meeting here in Brussels on Thursday and Friday to discuss that very opinion that came out of the European Commission last Friday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: A recommendation from Ursula von der Leyen and her commission to support Ukraine and Moldova, but not yet Georgia, to be candidates for EU membership.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And we heard lots of welcoming words today from ministers saying that this would be very symbolic and it would give a morale boost to Ukrainians who've been dying with the EU flag in their hand.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And Josip Borre, the EU Foreign Affairs Minister, was also very supportive of the move.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Take a listen now to what he had to say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The European Council later this week should send a signal and we start the preparation for the European integration of these three countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This is a powerful signal. It should be heard not only in Ukraine, not only in Moldova and Georgia, as a manifestation of our strength and unity and support to these three countries, and most especially to the one who has been, is is being aggressed by Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But whatever happens at that EU summit, Ukraine's membership talks will not start overnight. It will still be a long road ahead. There will be still hurdles to jump for Ukraine and Moldova, and of course, Georgia. All EU member states will then have to ratify the kicking off even of the negotiations, and then the tough talks will begin, and an member states will then have to ratify the kicking off even of the negotiations and then the tough talks will begin and an accession treaty will have to be drafted.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But if you look at the Ukrainians, they say they have 70% of the work already done and they're ready to tick all the long list on all the boxes they have to do in order to get what they need to do in order to get that membership of the European Union, something they really want.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: They do indeed and definitely a long road ahead for them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Thank you as always.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Intense fighting is continuing on Ukraine's eastern front

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: as defence forces look to thwart Russian efforts to seize full control of Severodonetsk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Elsewhere, Russia has stepped up airstrikes in and around Kharkiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Authorities say three children were injured, but Ukrainian troops have made steady progress in the largely Russian-controlled region of Kherson to the south. Local authorities claim that forces have advanced along the Dnieper River, destroying key Russian military stores. Well, let's now bring in Samuel Romani. He's associate fellow at the Royal United Services Institute.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Mr. Romani, thanks for joining us on Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, the battle for Severodonetsk looks to be coming to an end.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But where do you see Russia now pivoting when the city does perhaps finally fall?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, first of all, it's not a guarantee that Severodonetsk is going to fall extremely quickly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It's obvious that they've gotten control over 70 to 80 percent of the city, according to Ukrainian estimates, but Ukraine still controls the key industrial zone, and there's still a long battle in the chemical facility, which is going to be a smaller-scale version of the saga that we saw at the Azovstal Steelworks in Mariupol. So Severodonetsk is not gone, but the next step is going to most likely to be Lysyschansk, which will lead to the fall of Luhansk, and then crossovers in Donetsk, Odessa, where they launched 14 missile strikes around today, and of course, Kharkiv. Now, you mentioned the word saga there. The NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg, he's warned, of course, that the war in Ukraine could last years. Is that your take then? Well, my take is that it's going to last a very long time because even the Ukrainians are admitting that Russia's got the financial capabilities and the military wherewithal to carry out this war for another one to two years. A lot of the predictions that began in late March that Russia was running out of the kind of missiles and munitions that it would need to sustain the war in the long term haven't seemed to have panned out. Equally, the Ukrainians are not going to concede any scenario of which they lose substantial amounts of territory, like Luhansk and Kherson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: They're going to try to recapture those territories with a counteroffensive in July or August with new Western weaponry.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So the Ukrainians will be launching a counteroffensive, the Russians will be continuing their expansionism, and the result is a war that could definitely last years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So can you see Russia sitting down for any sort of peace talks or negotiations?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Not at this moment in time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I think it would probably take them being concerned about a tangible Ukrainian counteroffensive to come back to the table.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Because right now, the Russians are feeling ascendant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: They feel as if they've gotten the upper hand in Luhansk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And then they can cross the Siversky-Dunetsk River, go into Dunetsk, and then take over all of Siversky-Donetsk River, go into Donetsk, and then take over all of Donbass, and then complete the liberation of Donbass, which is what Dmitry Peshkov and other Russian officials have said was the core goal of the operation. So right now, the Russians are almost smug and confident about their position, so they probably aren't willing to engage in talks. But if the Ukrainians manage to gain a meaningful counteroffensive, get the kind of weaponry, artillery, even fighter jets down the line that they need, and the Russians start stalling in Kharkiv or Odessa, or if there's a hidden twist in Severodonetsk, which delays their capture of Luhansk, then we can see that maybe the Russians talking about dialogue again. So if this potentially is such a long protracted war, how much more long-term military, political and economic support do you think Western leaders can offer Kiev?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, the main thing is that the Western leaders stay the course.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I mean, Boris Johnson had an important point when he was warning of Ukraine fatigue, because that is possibly setting in as the Ukraine crisis is linked to rising food prices, linked to rising fuel prices.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: There's questions even amongst 30 percent of Americans in a recent Fox News survey about why are we giving money to Ukraine when we could be using that money to develop our own country. It's a midterm election coming up later this year in the States, a presidential election after that. So the main thing is that Western leaders keep their resolve and resist those kind of populist inclinations that might take them away from supporting Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But I think the movement in general still seems to be towards more howitzers, more AEPCs, more artillery at a slower pace than Ukraine would want, but the weapons are streaming in and that's going to be important for Ukraine as it tries to recapture lost territory and keep Russia from annexing Kharkiv and Odessa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Okay, Samuel Romani, we're going to leave it there, but thank you for joining us on the program tonight. Thank you so much. Germany has announced its latest steps to boost gas storage levels in preparation for the next winter season.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Over fears Russia could reduce or even completely halt supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russian state-controlled gas exporter Gazprom has cut deliveries by more than 60% in recent days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: by more than 60% in recent days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Germany's economy ministry says new measures to store gas will mean an increased reliance on coal-fired power plants.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The move marks a turnaround for the ruling coalition, which vowed to wind down its coal usage by 20% to 30%.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: For more, let's now cross over to Kate Brady in Berlin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Kate, so with the risk of supply shortages of gas, can Germany get its levels up in time for winter?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, that is the big question. As you say, there's so many factors at play right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Of course, Germany has been trying to reduce its dependency on Russian gas since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, something that critics had been calling on Germany to do for years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: On top of that, the gas storage facilities here in Germany are also down to just 57% now, something that Robert Habeck, the vice chancellor and German economy minister, who's said that these coal plants are going to be fired up again, he said that's just simply not going to be enough to get Germany through the winter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So, of course, Robert Habeck, the vice chancellor, being a green politician as well, THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: HE SAID THAT IS NOT GOING TO BE ENOUGH TO GET GERMANY THROUGH THE WINTER.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: ROBERT HAWK BEING A GREEN POLITICIAN, THIS IS A PARTICULARLY HARD MEASURE FOR HIM TO SWALLOW.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: GERMANY IS PLANNING ON FIRING UP MORE COAL PLANTS TO FILL THAT GAP THAT HAS BEEN LEFT BY THESE GAS SHORTAGES. by these gas shortages. But there are some other measures on the table as well. There's talks of a gas auction that would be aimed at huge industry. So we'd see big industry here being financially recompensated if they indeed reduce their gas consumption. And of course, consumers will be directly affected as well. There's even talk of a cap on domestic heating. So it really seems that nothing is off the table right now. And the German government is certainly scrambling to do everything it can to make sure that Germany can see itself through the winter now with these reduced gas supplies. They definitely do seem to be scrambling. But for Germany, Kate, it seems like it's one step forward, two steps back with them leaning back onto coal. Isn't this a bit of an embarrassment though. Given the EU commission has just recently unveiled its re power EU plan to really transform the bloc's energy system and move away from fossil fuels. Absolutely. And as you mentioned already, this government, this three party coalition government has indeed pledged to phase out coal fuelled energy by the end of 2030. And this is one of the huge concerns that's been voiced not only by environmental groups, but most recently by the UN as well, that climate protection pledges could indeed be jeopardized by countries like Germany trying to find new sources of energy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But Germany has really got itself in a rather special sticky situation, if you want to call it that, because, of course, we know, compared to some other countries, some other European neighbours as well, Germany has really under-invested in recent years, particularly in renewables.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So the situation that Germany finds itself in now is something that critics have indeed been warning about for years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It's worth pointing out as well, let's not forget, that Germany is also planning on phasing out the nuclear power plants here in Germany by the end of this year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So the situation right now very clearly is underlining once again this huge challenge facing so many countries right now when it comes to balancing those really three important factors when it comes to energy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Security of energy, the social impact, of course consumers are already feeling the pinch and seeing those energy prices rising here in Germany like across Europe and then of course not least of all the impact that that has on climate. So it really is an uphill battle here in Germany right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And the government is already sensitizing, if you will, trying to make the public more aware of what might be to come and how they can already reduce their energy consumption through a new national campaign, which I have to say isn't all that visible just yet, at least here in the German capital. It definitely does seem like, as you said, a special sticky situation for Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Kate Brady, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Emmanuel Macron's Ensemble Alliance has lost its absolute majority in the French National Assembly just two months after he was re-elected as president.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In France's parliamentary elections, Ensemble secured 245 seats, far below the 289 needed for a majority. They were followed by the left-wing coalition Noupes, led by Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon, who grabbed 141 seats in Sunday's vote. And Marine Le Pen's far-right party, the Rassemblement National, celebrated a historic breakthrough by obtaining 89 seats, jumping from the sixth to the third biggest party. Well our international correspondent Annelies Borges joins us now to rake over the aftermath of the French parliamentary results. Annelies always good to see you. So Macron has fallen short. So where does he go to next.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, the next few days will be very interesting here in France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Emmanuel Macron's camp, however, insists they will just forge on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Speaking shortly after those results were announced, the prime minister here of France, Elisabeth Borne, said that they are already negotiating what she described as a majority of action on behalf of the stability of the country and, of course, to be able to push through some of the ambitious reforms Emmanuel Macron has planned.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But, of course, that won't be easy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He will either have to cobble together some sort of report of support, rather, for each piece of legislation, or he'll have to negotiate a more permanent base of support. And many political analysts here in this country are suggesting that the most compatible ally would be the Conservative Party, the Republican.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But the leader of that party has already come forward saying that they will not negotiate with the government, that they will remain in the opposition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So basically Emmanuel Macron has two options from now on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: the opposition. So basically Emmanuel Macron has two options from now on. If indeed he is not able to negotiate a better solution and a more permanent base of support he will either have to negotiate through to have to govern rather through what the French have learned to call the count of what the forty nine point three. That's an article of the Constitution that allows for the prime minister to ram through legislation without a parliamentary debate. But that of course is just a temporary solution because within 24 hours if a majority in parliament decides that the legislation adopted by the prime minister is not compatible with France they can overturn it. Another option of course if there is a major political crisis a major deadlock in parliament. Emmanuel Macron could call for new elections, but that will take some time. That will take at least a year. So it's going to be very interesting to see where the governing group of Emmanuel Macron goes to next. Some analysts are in fact playing the whole thing down, saying that people here in France, leaders here in France have governed with a minority before. The only condition for that to happen is that other political forces don't unite against the government. And of course, with the two political forces in parliament now being the far left and the far right, that is very unlikely to happen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So tough times looming potentially for negotiations for Emmanuel Macron.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Let's come to Marine Le Pen and her party, the third largest bloc in Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: What does this then mean for French politics going forward, Annelies?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, this is a historic moment for Marine Le Pen's national rally, jumping from eight seats to 89, becoming the third largest force in France right now, political force in France right now, and able to form a parliamentary group. That means they get more speaking time, but also more weight on the political debate within the walls of the National Assembly, but also beyond that institution. Earlier today, the leader of the movement, Marine Le Pen, has put rather bluntly what this all means for the administration of Emmanuel Macron. Take a listen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Will Emmanuel Macron be able to do what he wants? No. The answer is no. That is to say,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I think that retirement at 65 is a buried reform, as well as a whole series of other measures that Emmanuel Macron wanted to put in place and which in reality were toxic for the French people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Marine Le Pen, who has been celebrating this historical victory for her party, a victory that will also mean a financing boost for the national rally. They will get about 10 million euros a year for the votes that they have managed to secure. That will certainly be welcome in a party that has some 24 million euros in debt. Changing times indeed for France. Annalise, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Okay, well, France wasn't the only country voting last weekend. Spain's Conservative People's Party won a historic majority in the regional elections in the region of Andalusia on Sunday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Mario Boden reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: A historic win for the right wing in the Andalusian elections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Throughout Sunday night and into the early hours of Monday morning, supporters of the Partido Popular in Seville and several other Andalusian cities celebrated a victory with an absolute majority.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The Popular Party has obtained the best electoral result in Spain's most populated autonomous community.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Juan Manuel Moreno's candidacy has managed to oust the Socialist Party from what was its own fiefdom for more than 35 years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Andalusia is going to have four years of prosperity, of progress, of improvement, of moving forward, of continuing to manage the interests of Andalusia with honesty, transparency, moderation and serenity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We're going to do it for four more years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The Andalusian right won 58 of the 109 deputies, an absolute majority that exempts them from having to make a pact with the extreme right of Vox, which won 13% of the votes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The left-wing parties, led by the Socialists and followed by two other candidates, suffered a drop of 13 deputies compared to 2018.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The result is a boost for the right and a spur to unite forces on the left in the run-up to the 2023 Spanish general elections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Mario Boden, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This year, war in Ukraine and other conflicts

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: has seen the number of forcibly displaced people surge to its highest level in years. David Morakun reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The refugee crisis provoked by the war in Ukraine has refocused attention on the plight of displaced people as the international community marks World Refugee Day. Millions have fled the fighting in Ukraine, adding to the latest annual figures released by the UN.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In total, close to 90 million people are considered forcibly displaced across the planet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: After years of relative stability, the figure has surged, more than doubling in the past decade.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The number officially seeking asylum surpassed 4.5 million in 2021. Germany was the EU country that received the highest number of new applications.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Turkey hosts more forcibly displaced people than any other country, with more than 3.8 million. Across the world, just four countries have taken in almost a third of all refugees.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: War and persecution remain the cause of displacement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Until the invasion of Ukraine, which isn't included in this latest report, the enduring Syrian conflict was the principal source of flight from fighting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Almost half of all refugees came from a handful of countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In addition to Syria, the list includes South Sudan, Myanmar and Afghanistan, with more than 88% of Afghan refugees hosted in Pakistan and Iran.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The report also gives special consideration to the situation in Venezuela, which the UNHCR categorizes as the second largest external displacement crisis in the world, with some six million refugees and migrants from Venezuela located worldwide.
